text: The final 24 hours of Flash's death clock seem like a good occasion to think about the non-linear nature of art-making tool development. I suppose I'm a technological determinist, and the larger forces that hashed out browser standards--nurturing Flash for a time, and then abruptly extinguishing it--don't seem all that historically different from, for example, the 1979 global silver shortage, which by suddenly raising the price of film stock greatly accelerated the shift to video.

text: I've also had an interesting related perspective starting a PhD at York University in Toronto this year; I used to teach there as an adjunct ten years ago, and now I get to catch up with the way coding gets taught to artists in the same institution's art and design programs a decade later.

text: Turns out that the institutional memory from back then seems to have vanished--which is ironic given that a chunk of what ended up becoming HTML5 (contributions to WebGL, Web Audio, and processing.js, ancestor of p5.js) was actually developed there.

text: From what I can piece together this was the accidental overlap of a design department head who'd pushed for more Processing curriculum, and an on-campus community college program (the Seneca Centre for Development of Open Technology) with a Mozilla-affiliated CS prof who led processing.js development as a use case for WebGL. The design prof retired, the community college moved to a separate campus, Mozilla stopped funding processing.js, and it doesn't seem like the art and design schools universally embraced p5.js as its logical successor.

text: So of course JS frameworks and WebGL still get taught, piecemeal--it's just that as far as I know, nobody is left to remember that the university had a historical connection to these specific technologies. Bringing things back to Flash--more than any particular features, I think it was the continuity of tool use in a community that made it special, persisting for about fifteen years. In York's case, I wonder what an additional decade of experimentation with a single framework--a time spanning three full cohorts of undergraduates--might have brought.

text: Ursula Franklin has a bit about the difference between "holistic" technology, where a single generalist can learn the process from beginning to end (regardless of whether they do the work alone or in a group)...vs. "prescriptive" technology where the process needs to be broken down into steps to be carried out by multiple specialists, and no individual specialist can go through every step of the process themselves.
